Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. This study also provides a new method to study the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels. This method can be applied to other proton channels. This study will also provide valuable information for understanding the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits other ion channels.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile: The median business with more than $10,000 in monthly expenses had only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. We also assess take-up rates and business resilience effects for loans relative to grants-based programs. Our results suggest that grants may be a more effective way to support small businesses during the COVID-19 crisis.

The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System 4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. These grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for understanding the formation of the Solar System.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental trait of all organisms. In humans, the average woman has 100–150 children in her lifetime. In contrast, the average human female has only one or two children. This dramatic difference is due to the ability of humans to increase their reproductive output through the practice of allonursing. Allonursing is the practice of nursing a surrogate mother’s young. We show that allonursing is associated with increased reproductive output in mammals. This suggests that the ability to increase reproductive output is a fundamental trait of all mammals. We also show that the practice of allonursing is associated with increased litter size without compromising offspring size. This suggests that the practice of allonursing is a key factor in increasing reproductive output. All forms of external energetic supplementation correlate with increased reproductive output. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of mammals.

The COVIDcast API is our attempt to fill this need: Operational since April 2020, it provides open access to both traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. All of the data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is heterochronic, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed at higher levels than adult hemoglobin (HbA). Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is down-regulated in fetal liver. IGF2BP1 overexpression in erythroid cells causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is known to repress HbF expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of HbF and HbA expression in humans. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of sickle cell disease.

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure, but the mechanism is unknown. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling pathways that promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in hypertension. It also provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that transformed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition. However, against our expectations, declines of older forests accelerated. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to forest management that considers the full range of ecosystem services and biodiversity. This is especially important in the Pacific Northwest, where the NWFP is a unique policy that provides a rare opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings provide a cautionary tale for other regions that are considering similar policies. We must learn from the past to ensure that the future of forest policy is more sustainable.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on the PASCAL VOC 2012 segmentation benchmark. The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4–deficient mice developed lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in autoimmunity. It also provides a model for congenital CTLA-4 deficiency. This study will help to understand the role of CTLA-4 in autoimmunity.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that participates in normal synapse turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic synapse pruning. APOE2 enhances the rate of astrocytic synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. It also suggests that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet, with a density of 13.08 g/cm3, which is 13 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed by the rapid solidification of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. Using a persistent embryo method and molecular dynamics simulations, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process. Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in machine learning, but its stability has been a major concern. This paper establishes a classification theory for stability of neural networks. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This theory is based on the notion of fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify to be stable. Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which infects peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the upper respiratory tract. The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is poorly understood. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the causes of this trend and the problems that are being created. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The genetic landscape of Europe is a complex mosaic of genetic contributions from different parts of the continent and from outside. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change from the Roman to the Early Medieval period is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides a unique window into the genetic history of Europe during a period of cultural change. It also provides a resource for future studies of the genetic history of Europe.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, we used in vitro evolution to improve the activity of a ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the impacts on the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a new genus and species, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. The rate at which the global mean sea level is rising is a key indicator of climate change. We estimate that the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y is 2.9 ± 0.4 mm/y, which is in agreement with the 5th Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This implies that the rate of sea level rise could increase by 0.5 ± 0.2 mm/y by 2015–2020 and by 1.0 ± 0.5 mm/y by 2025–2030. This is in agreement with the 5th Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the acceleration is likely due to climate change. This is the first time that a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data has been used to estimate the rate of sea level rise and its acceleration.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the sensory dendrite or mutations disrupting sensory activity, calcium signaling, or genes that restrict outgrowth during neuronal maturation. These connections suggest that ectopic outgrowth represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work provides a framework for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the adult nervous system’s regenerative capacity. It also provides a platform for discovering novel therapeutic targets for restoring regeneration capacity in the adult nervous system. This work is particularly timely, given the recent identification of a rare form of ALS/FTD that is caused by mutations in a gene encoding a protein that is a direct target of DLK signaling.

The process of meiosis is essential for sexual reproduction, but the molecular mechanisms that regulate recombination during meiosis are poorly understood. We use shotgun resequencing of a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus to precisely locate over 400,000 boundaries of historic crossovers or gene conversion tracts. Their distribution defines some 13,000 hotspots of varying strengths, interspersed with cold regions of undetectably low recombination. Average recombination rates peak near starts of genes and fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity. Within genes, recombination tracts are more likely to terminate in exons than in introns. The general pattern is similar to that observed in yeast, as well as in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This study provides a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, which is the most diverse lineage of seed plants. The results may help to elucidate the evolution of recombination in plants and eukaryotes more generally. This study also provides a resource for studying the genetic architecture of recombination in a flowering plant. The shotgun sequencing data are available at the Dryad Digital Repository

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) demonstrated that intensive glycemic control reduced the risk of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of intensive therapy on the progression of complications are unknown. We studied epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) alterations in whole blood and monocytes of people with diabetes during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and found that DNA-me alterations at specific loci persisted for several years after the DCCT. These DNA-me alterations were associated with glycemia in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies are needed to determine whether DNA-me alterations at these loci can be targeted to improve metabolic memory. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease with high morbidity and mortality. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects and that this alteration is associated with psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. Probiotics may be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Global warming and biodiversity loss are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities had a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enabled them to maintain productivity as temperatures shifted from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment and the animal's position within it. The cell types that comprise MEC are organized into distinct layers, but how these layers are arranged in space is unknown. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the activity of neurons in MEC while mice freely explored an open field. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal's position in space, are organized into distinct layers. These data suggest that the organization of MEC is more complex than previously thought. They also provide a framework for future studies of the neural basis of navigation. The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This work provides a new way to measure and understand social connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN automaticity is regulated by specialized SANCs that are enriched in Ca2+ stores and have unique electrophysiological properties. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and regulates Ca2+ release from stores and Ca2+ entry through store-operated channels. We also show that STIM1 regulates the activity of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger and a store-operated Ca2+ current in SANCs. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function. These findings may help in understanding the pathogenesis of arrhythmogenic disorders of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential micronutrient for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. Although Si has been shown to confer resistance against abiotic stresses, its role in mediating resistance against insect herbivores has not been well documented. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the insect herbivore Cnaphalocrocis medinalis (rice leaffolder) in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate biosynthesis or perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA is mediated by the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si and JA interact in rice plants to mediate resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanism for the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores. Understanding the mechanisms by which Si and JA interact in plants may provide insights into the use of Si as a biocontrol agent. (Received October 22, 2015. Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory storage in the nervous system that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory storage, but that changes in the excitability of individual neurons is a simpler and more direct way to store information. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a mechanism for memory storage that is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. Memory span is systematically related to both the time constant of adaptation and baseline levels of neuronal excitability. Interference effects within memory arise when adaptation is long lasting. NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause an autoimmune encephalitis with a diverse range of EEG abnormalities. Using this model, we then identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we use the mouse model to show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid global warming. Understanding the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming is therefore of utmost importance. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a global-scale organic matter–derived C injection and anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that the warming was linked to enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. Our study provides insights into the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming and the potential impacts of anthropogenic global warming. It also highlights the importance of organic matter in the Earth system.

Vertebrate sex determination is a complex process that has been studied for over 100 y. The retina is challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe is a key regulator of bisretinoid metabolism. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Fe in the retina and may inform strategies to protect against retinal disease. Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) for prey capture. The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is incomplete, and the origin of the distinctive morphology of the modern human hand is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from West Turkana, Kenya, that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. The discovery of this fossil also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study provides new insights into the evolution of the human hand. It also highlights the potential for the discovery of new hominin fossils in East Africa. Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits.
